qas.question: What is the written law of the Torah known as?
Who dictated the oral law to Moses?
What are the detailed explanations of how to apply and interpret the laws of the written Torah called?
What is the law that is considered the core of religious laws Orthodox Jews know today?
What is the origin of Jewish Law?
Which single part of the Law do Orthodox Jews hold to be dictated by God?
What parts of the oral law are different than the original dictation?
What was not given a clear explanations on how to apply it?
Who added fences to historical law that are not a part of modern day?
What is considered divine and in no need of interpretation?

context: Orthodox Judaism holds that the words of the Torah, including both the <b5_0>Written Law<b5_0/> (<a0_0>Pentateuch<a0_0/>) and those parts of the Oral Law which are "<b6_0>halacha leMoshe m'Sinai<b6_0/>", were dictated by <a1_0>God<a1_0/> to Moses essentially as they exist today. The laws contained in the Written <b7_0>Torah<b7_0/> were given along with detailed explanations as how to apply and interpret them, the <a2_0>Oral Law<a2_0/>. Although Orthodox Jews believe that many elements of current religious law were decreed or added as "fences" around the law by the <b8_0>rabbis<b8_0/>, all Orthodox Jews believe that there is an underlying core of <a3_0>Sinaitic law<a3_0/> and that this core of the religious laws Orthodox Jews know today is thus directly derived from Sinai and directly reflects the Divine will. As such, Orthodox Jews believe that one must be extremely careful in interpreting Jewish law. Orthodox Judaism holds that, given <b9_0>Jewish law's<b9_0/> <a4_0>Divine<a4_0/> origin, no underlying principle may be compromised in accounting for changing political, social or economic conditions; in this sense, "creativity" and development in Jewish law is limited.
